newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EP to demand withdrawal of Commission notice.
newsitem.headline: EP to demand withdrawal of Commission notice.

text.p: The European Parliament is due next week to criticise the way the European Commission is attempting to prise open the European Union market in postal services.

Competition Commissioner Karel Van Miert has said that if EU telecoms ministers failed by December 31, 1996 to agree to EU rules on liberalising postal services, the Commission would publish a notice setting out how it would apply competition rules to the sector.
The Telecoms Council failed on November 28 to reach agreement and is not due to reconvene until next year.
In a report due to be approved on December 11, Euro-MPs are expected to say they agree with the need to liberalise the EU postal sector soon.
But they will insist the way to achieve this is for the Council to approve the draft directive, COM(95)227, and not for the Commission to take unprecedented unilateral action.

In a draft of the notice published last year, the Commission set out which services could be "reserved" for state post offices, proposed limits on "cross-subsidies" (money from monopoly services used to subsidise competitive ones), and said public postal operators must offer competitors non-discriminatory access to their networks.
The EP report, drafted by French Christian Democrat Georges Bremond d'Ars, argues that the draft notice contradicts the draft directive and should be withdrawn.
Bremond d'Ars also says that publishing the notice would run counter to the Commission's promise to ensure the definitions used in both texts would be identical.
Logically, it cannot do so until the Council and the parliament have agreed on the final form the draft directive will take, he says.

"The length of time (six years) it has taken the Commission to draw up its proposals and drafts cannot today justify excessive haste in adopting a text which, far from regulating competition problems in the postal sector, would merely complicate them," the report concludes.
